newsitem.title: USA: Fed seen adding temporary reserves, funds tight.
newsitem.headline: Fed seen adding temporary reserves, funds tight.

text.p: A firm Federal funds rate, reflecting year- and period-end pressures on reserves, means the Federal Reserve will add temporary reserves to the banking system on Monday, analysts said.
Forecasts for the precise operation the Fed's open market desk would undertake included overnight system repurchase agreements or term system repurchases.
"We expect term system repo's, but there's a risk of overnight repo's," said Kim Rupert, senior economist at MMS International.
James Blumenthal, economist at MCM MoneyWatch, said he expects the Fed to add temporary reserves via overnight system repurchase agreements.
"You have a fairly large add need, but you do have some system RPs outstanding," he said, referring to 13- and 14-day system repurchase agreements the Fed has recently conducted.
But Blumenthal noted that the four-day system that the Fed did on Thursday "runs off today so that definitely needs to be replaced."
Federal funds traded at 5-1/2 percent in early activity, above the Fed's 5-1/4 percent target for the rate.
"Funds are very tight due to year-end pressures," said Rupert. "Banks need funds to close up their books.
"Also, period-end pressures are creeping in," she said, referring to the end of the two-week bank reserve maintenance period on Wednesday.
